values.description:
** Post Blueprint **

This adds support for an RGBD Camera sensor. While working on the SubT sensor models I discovered that we did not account for this: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/src/default/subt_sensors/urdf/rgbd_camera.urdf.xacro

## Requires ##

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/70
* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/132
* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/540

values.description:
Add support for loading only the submesh when the `<submesh>` element is specified in a visual.

For testing, here's a [world file](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/iche033/zegEex) containing a fuel model that uses the `<submesh>` element. The walls, ground, lights, metal chains, and wood in this tunnel tile model have been separated into individual submeshes so we can associate them with their own PBR textures.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3199538565-tunnel_tile_pbr.png)
values.title: Parse and load submesh geometry in visuals

summary.raw:
Add support for loading only the submesh when the `<submesh>` element is specified in a visual.

For testing, here's a [world file](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/iche033/zegEex) containing a fuel model that uses the `<submesh>` element. The walls, ground, lights, metal chains, and wood in this tunnel tile model have been separated into individual submeshes so we can associate them with their own PBR textures.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3199538565-tunnel_tile_pbr.png)
summary.html:
Add support for loading only the submesh when the <submesh> element is specified in a visual.

For testing, here's a world file containing a fuel model that uses the <submesh> element. The walls, ground, lights, metal chains, and wood in this tunnel tile model have been separated into individual submeshes so we can associate them with their own PBR textures.

values.description:
Port track drive vehicle support from Gazebo9, which was originally added in this pull request: [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2652/added-support-for-tracked-vehicles/](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2652/added-support-for-tracked-vehicles/) .

* Emulate tracks using overlapping wheels, which makes the code basically the same as that for DiffDrive.
* Need friction cone model for proper steering, which appears to not be in Dart.
* The Contact Surface Motion method requires friction cone model in order to work, so it is not implemented yet.
values.title: Add track drive vehicle system

summary.raw:
Port track drive vehicle support from Gazebo9, which was originally added in this pull request: [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2652/added-support-for-tracked-vehicles/](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2652/added-support-for-tracked-vehicles/) .

* Emulate tracks using overlapping wheels, which makes the code basically the same as that for DiffDrive.
* Need friction cone model for proper steering, which appears to not be in Dart.
* The Contact Surface Motion method requires friction cone model in order to work, so it is not implemented yet.
summary.html:
Port track drive vehicle support from Gazebo9, which was originally added in this pull request: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2652/added-support-for-tracked-vehicles/ .

  • Emulate tracks using overlapping wheels, which makes the code basically the same as that for DiffDrive.
  • Need friction cone model for proper steering, which appears to not be in Dart.
  • The Contact Surface Motion method requires friction cone model in order to work, so it is not implemented yet.

values.description:
The log playback system fails to parse the state log file if I try to play it back from a different location than the one it’s created in. The problem is that the log filepath is [embedded](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/0c60411df5f6b4a0c9b6f7fb9ea3b91e7f068f5b/src/systems/log/LogRecord.cc#lines-205) in the sdf topic in the recorded log file, and the playback system relies on the assumption that the log location is in the same path in order to read the sdf string back.

This PR updates the log playback system to do an additional path-independent check to find the sdf topic when playing back the state log. Also updated the log system integration test to demonstrate playing back a state log file from a different location.
values.title: Support log playback from a different path

summary.raw:
The log playback system fails to parse the state log file if I try to play it back from a different location than the one it’s created in. The problem is that the log filepath is [embedded](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/0c60411df5f6b4a0c9b6f7fb9ea3b91e7f068f5b/src/systems/log/LogRecord.cc#lines-205) in the sdf topic in the recorded log file, and the playback system relies on the assumption that the log location is in the same path in order to read the sdf string back.

This PR updates the log playback system to do an additional path-independent check to find the sdf topic when playing back the state log. Also updated the log system integration test to demonstrate playing back a state log file from a different location.
summary.html:
The log playback system fails to parse the state log file if I try to play it back from a different location than the one it’s created in. The problem is that the log filepath is embedded in the sdf topic in the recorded log file, and the playback system relies on the assumption that the log location is in the same path in order to read the sdf string back.

This PR updates the log playback system to do an additional path-independent check to find the sdf topic when playing back the state log. Also updated the log system integration test to demonstrate playing back a state log file from a different location.

values.description:
The initialized state is now set [later in the render system](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/a1535b8ffc7cf751deb4f31495030499813dfdfe/src/rendering/RenderUtil.cc#lines-463). This line was removed in pull request #350 but reintroduced again in pull request #351 probably from a bad merge.

Without this change, you may run into the white screen problem or an error msg below if you have a camera sensor in the world:

`[Err] [SceneManager.cc:151] Parent entity with Id: [368] not found. Not adding link: [369]`
values.title: Fix rendering intialization

summary.raw:
The initialized state is now set [later in the render system](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/a1535b8ffc7cf751deb4f31495030499813dfdfe/src/rendering/RenderUtil.cc#lines-463). This line was removed in pull request #350 but reintroduced again in pull request #351 probably from a bad merge.

Without this change, you may run into the white screen problem or an error msg below if you have a camera sensor in the world:

`[Err] [SceneManager.cc:151] Parent entity with Id: [368] not found. Not adding link: [369]`
summary.html:
The initialized state is now set later in the render system. This line was removed in pull request #350 but reintroduced again in pull request #351 probably from a bad merge.

Without this change, you may run into the white screen problem or an error msg below if you have a camera sensor in the world:

[Err] [SceneManager.cc:151] Parent entity with Id: [368] not found. Not adding link: [369]

values.description: Apparently, DART and  Ignition Physics don't use `rand()` functions, so no need to propagate the seed towards Ignition Physics as we used to do in Gazebo classic.
values.title: Custom random seed

summary.raw: Apparently, DART and  Ignition Physics don't use `rand()` functions, so no need to propagate the seed towards Ignition Physics as we used to do in Gazebo classic.
summary.html: Apparently, DART and Ignition Physics don't use rand() functions, so no need to propagate the seed towards Ignition Physics as we used to do in Gazebo classic.

values.description: Not setting the `<topic>` parameter in rendering sensors (camera, depth camera, rgbd camera, and gpu_lidar) causes ign-gazebo to crash. This PR addresses this by setting a default topic for these sensors with the pattern `/world/<world name>/model/<model name>/link/<link name>/sensor/<sensor name>/<suffix>`.
values.title: Set default topics for rendering sensors

summary.raw: Not setting the `<topic>` parameter in rendering sensors (camera, depth camera, rgbd camera, and gpu_lidar) causes ign-gazebo to crash. This PR addresses this by setting a default topic for these sensors with the pattern `/world/<world name>/model/<model name>/link/<link name>/sensor/<sensor name>/<suffix>`.
summary.html: Not setting the <topic> parameter in rendering sensors (camera, depth camera, rgbd camera, and gpu_lidar) causes ign-gazebo to crash. This PR addresses this by setting a default topic for these sensors with the pattern /world/<world name>/model/<model name>/link/<link name>/sensor/<sensor name>/<suffix>.

values.description:
A deadlock was observed when spawning models into the world through the `UserCommands `system. 

The system locks a mutex in order to process a list of commands. Later service calls will be blocked until the current command is fully processed. However, it seems like if the model being spawned has plugins that also makes service call, it causes a deadlock

Fixed by making a copy of commands so execution of the command does not lock incoming services calls. 

‌

I ran into the problem when spawning multiple robots in subt. Example cmd to reproduce the problem:

```
ign launch -v 4 src/subt/subt_ign/launch/virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X2_3 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X3_3 robotConfig2:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_2 robotName3:=X4_3 robotConfig3:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_4 robotName4:=X1_3 robotConfig4:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName5:=X2_2 robotConfig5:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_2 robotName6:=X6 robotConfig6:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```
values.title: Fix deadlock when spawning robots

summary.raw:
A deadlock was observed when spawning models into the world through the `UserCommands `system. 

The system locks a mutex in order to process a list of commands. Later service calls will be blocked until the current command is fully processed. However, it seems like if the model being spawned has plugins that also makes service call, it causes a deadlock

Fixed by making a copy of commands so execution of the command does not lock incoming services calls. 

‌

I ran into the problem when spawning multiple robots in subt. Example cmd to reproduce the problem:

```
ign launch -v 4 src/subt/subt_ign/launch/virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X2_3 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X3_3 robotConfig2:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_2 robotName3:=X4_3 robotConfig3:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_4 robotName4:=X1_3 robotConfig4:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName5:=X2_2 robotConfig5:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_2 robotName6:=X6 robotConfig6:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```
summary.html:
A deadlock was observed when spawning models into the world through the UserCommandssystem.

The system locks a mutex in order to process a list of commands. Later service calls will be blocked until the current command is fully processed. However, it seems like if the model being spawned has plugins that also makes service call, it causes a deadlock

Fixed by making a copy of commands so execution of the command does not lock incoming services calls.

‌

I ran into the problem when spawning multiple robots in subt. Example cmd to reproduce the problem:

ign launch -v 4 src/subt/subt_ign/launch/virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X2_3 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X3_3 robotConfig2:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_2 robotName3:=X4_3 robotConfig3:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_4 robotName4:=X1_3 robotConfig4:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName5:=X2_2 robotConfig5:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_2 robotName6:=X6 robotConfig6:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

values.description:
This allows the simulation runner to publish to the root `/clock` topic if no other simulator is currently running.

I verified the behavior by spinning up two `ign gazebo -v 4` in sequence:

  
On the first:

```
[Msg] Found no publishers on /clock, adding root clock topic
```

On the second:

```
[Wrn] [SimulationRunner.cc:428] Found additional publishers on /clock, using namespaced clock topic only
[Dbg] [SimulationRunner.cc:430] Publishers [Address, Message Type]:
[Dbg] [SimulationRunner.cc:436]   tcp://172.17.0.1:43337, ignition.msgs.Clock
```

‌

Also can be verified via `ign topic` \(both running the default world\).

```
$ ign topic -i -t /clock
Publishers [Address, Message Type]:
  tcp://172.17.0.1:43337, ignition.msgs.Clock
  
$ ign topic -i -t /world/default/clock
Publishers [Address, Message Type]:
  tcp://172.17.0.1:43337, ignition.msgs.Clock
  tcp://172.17.0.1:40865, ignition.msgs.Clock
```
values.title: Additionally publish root /clock topic if no other simulation running

values.description:
This requires a few pull requests:

1. #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/141
2. #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/315

Easiest way to test this:

1. Inside the `ign-launch` examples folder:

```
ign launch gazebo_plugins.ign -v 4
```

2. Echo an odometry topic:

```
ign topic -et /model/vehicle_blue/odometry
```

3. Joystick the robots. Driving them in a circle should cause odometry to return back to zero.
values.title: Update and publish odometry

values.description:
This prevents the generation of the `poseMsg` and `dyPoseMsg` if there are no subscribers. Testing on


improves performance from ~40% to ~65%.

Recording a state log file will limit the usefulness of this change.

values.description:
Final PR in this series of performance improvements. This requires: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/143.

The main changes:

1. A `msgs::SerializedStateMap` message is used to help keep track of entities and components in a message so that we don't have to keep creating new messages.

2. A component knows when it has changed. Only changed components are serialized in the `msgs::SerializedStateMap`. This prevents static models from being serialized every iteration.

The major drawback to this PR is that log files generated by a previous version are not compatible with this change because the of the msgs change.

You should be able to run the example tunnel world faster than realtime. I saw between 110 and 120%.

```
ign gazebo -v 4 tunnel.sdf -z 100000 -r
```
values.title: Nate testing scenebroad improvements

summary.raw:
Final PR in this series of performance improvements. This requires: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/143.

The main changes:

1. A `msgs::SerializedStateMap` message is used to help keep track of entities and components in a message so that we don't have to keep creating new messages.

2. A component knows when it has changed. Only changed components are serialized in the `msgs::SerializedStateMap`. This prevents static models from being serialized every iteration.

The major drawback to this PR is that log files generated by a previous version are not compatible with this change because the of the msgs change.

You should be able to run the example tunnel world faster than realtime. I saw between 110 and 120%.

```

```
summary.html:
Final PR in this series of performance improvements. This requires: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/143.

The main changes:

  1. A msgs::SerializedStateMap message is used to help keep track of entities and components in a message so that we don't have to keep creating new messages.

  2. A component knows when it has changed. Only changed components are serialized in the msgs::SerializedStateMap. This prevents static models from being serialized every iteration.

The major drawback to this PR is that log files generated by a previous version are not compatible with this change because the of the msgs change.

You should be able to run the example tunnel world faster than realtime. I saw between 110 and 120%.

ign gazebo -v 4 tunnel.sdf -z 100000 -r

values.description:
When computing the new pose of model, we are actually **post-multiplying** the link’s pose relative to world by the inverse of link’s pose relative to model.

The computation in the code:

```
_pose->Data().Inverse() + math::eigen3::convert(worldPose));
```

of \(poseA \+ poseB\) is indeed \(matrixB \* matrixA\).
values.title: Fix an error in comment

summary.raw:
When computing the new pose of model, we are actually **post-multiplying** the link’s pose relative to world by the inverse of link’s pose relative to model.

The computation in the code:

```
_pose->Data().Inverse() + math::eigen3::convert(worldPose));
```

of \(poseA \+ poseB\) is indeed \(matrixB \* matrixA\).
summary.html:
When computing the new pose of model, we are actually post-multiplying the link’s pose relative to world by the inverse of link’s pose relative to model.

The computation in the code:

_pose->Data().Inverse() + math::eigen3::convert(worldPose));

of (poseA + poseB) is indeed (matrixB * matrixA).

values.description:
Alternative to pull request #378.

Introduces 3 possible component changed states.

The broadcaster sends the full state if there are one-time component changes. Otherwise, it only sends all changed poses (periodic and one-time).
values.title: Periodic / One-time component changes

summary.raw:
Alternative to pull request #378.

Introduces 3 possible component changed states.

The broadcaster sends the full state if there are one-time component changes. Otherwise, it only sends all changed poses (periodic and one-time).
summary.html:
Alternative to pull request #378.

Introduces 3 possible component changed states.

The broadcaster sends the full state if there are one-time component changes. Otherwise, it only sends all changed poses (periodic and one-time).

values.description: We broke distributed sim somewhere along the way. This PR fixes the two examples under `examples/scripts`.
values.title: [Blueprint] Fix distributed sim

summary.raw: We broke distributed sim somewhere along the way. This PR fixes the two examples under `examples/scripts`.

values.description:
Depends on [ign-sensors pull request #81](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/81/support-manual-scene-updates-for-rendering/diff)

This updates the sensor system to make use of the manual scene update mode introduced in the [ign-sensors pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/81/support-manual-scene-updates-for-rendering/diff).

I have been testing with one of the subt tunnel circuit practice worlds. For convenience, here’s a [world sdf file](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/iche033/Lj46XM/profilesdf) that strips out subt related systems and can be run using `ign gazebo`. I added 5 HD cameras @ 30Hz in the world. With this PR, the sensor manager update time reduced from at 0.08x to 0.04x seconds
values.title: [Blueprint] Bundle scene updates in sensor system

Depends on [ign-sensors pull request #81](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/81/support-manual-scene-updates-for-rendering/diff)

I added 5 HD cameras @ 30Hz in the world. With this PR, the sensor manager update time reduced from at 0.08x to 0.04x seconds
summary.html:
Depends on ign-sensors pull request #81

This updates the sensor system to make use of the manual scene update mode introduced in the ign-sensors pull request.

I have been testing with one of the subt tunnel circuit practice worlds. For convenience, here’s a world sdf file that strips out subt related systems and can be run using ign gazebo. I added 5 HD cameras @ 30Hz in the world. With this PR, the sensor manager update time reduced from at 0.08x to 0.04x seconds

values.description:
The general idea here is put each of the `PostUpdate` calls \(for systems that implement them\) in their own worker thread. They are syncronized via two barriers \(which isn’t in the C\+\+ standard yet\).

Creating a thread and using a barrier ends up being slightly more efficient than the ign::common::WorkerPool, because we aren’t creating and destroying WorkOrders in each loop. This is only really possible because we’re making the same function calls repeatedly.

The barriers will block until all threads have reached the `barrier.wait()` call. This is why the barriers are constructed with a count of `number of postupdates + 1 (for the main thread)`

Edit:

This now includes a worker thread for rendering sensors, causing rendering updates to happen in parallel with the main thread.  In the case that a new rendering operation is required, the main thread will block until the previous one is complete.  

This generally eliminates frames that substantially overran their allotted time \(a rendering update could take 30-60x the allotted time\).
values.title: Add worker threads for System PostUpdate phase

summary.raw:
The general idea here is put each of the `PostUpdate` calls \(for systems that implement them\) in their own worker thread. They are syncronized via two barriers \(which isn’t in the C\+\+ standard yet\).

Creating a thread and using a barrier ends up being slightly more efficient than the ign::common::WorkerPool, because we aren’t creating and destroying WorkOrders in each loop. This is only really possible because we’re making the same function calls repeatedly.

The barriers will block until all threads have reached the `barrier.wait()` call. This is why the barriers are constructed with a count of `number of postupdates + 1 (for the main thread)`

Edit:

This now includes a worker thread for rendering sensors, causing rendering updates to happen in parallel with the main thread.  In the case that a new rendering operation is required, the main thread will block until the previous one is complete.  

This generally eliminates frames that substantially overran their allotted time \(a rendering update could take 30-60x the allotted time\).
summary.html:
The general idea here is put each of the PostUpdate calls (for systems that implement them) in their own worker thread. They are syncronized via two barriers (which isn’t in the C++ standard yet).

Creating a thread and using a barrier ends up being slightly more efficient than the ign::common::WorkerPool, because we aren’t creating and destroying WorkOrders in each loop. This is only really possible because we’re making the same function calls repeatedly.

The barriers will block until all threads have reached the barrier.wait() call. This is why the barriers are constructed with a count of number of postupdates + 1 (for the main thread)

Edit:

This now includes a worker thread for rendering sensors, causing rendering updates to happen in parallel with the main thread. In the case that a new rendering operation is required, the main thread will block until the previous one is complete.

This generally eliminates frames that substantially overran their allotted time (a rendering update could take 30-60x the allotted time).

values.description:
Per request from community, this pull request publishes battery state constantly in a topic.

‌

This pull request depends on:

1. [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/145](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/145)

To test it:

Launch the example world:

`ign gazebo -v 4 linear_battery_demo.sdf`

Monitor the battery soc topic:

`ign topic -e -t /model/vehicle_blue/battery/linear_battery/state`

Move the robot:

`ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 6.0} angular: {z: 0.4}"`
values.title: Publish battery state of charge in a topic

values.description:
A runner for executing an SDF and recording simulation rates.

Can be used in conjunction with the plotting script to do

`--summarize` to get statistics about RTF

`--plot` to display a plot of RTF vs sim time

`--hist` to display a histogram of RTF.
values.title: Sdf runner performance executor and scripts

summary.raw:
A runner for executing an SDF and recording simulation rates.

Can be used in conjunction with the plotting script to do

`--summarize` to get statistics about RTF

`--plot` to display a plot of RTF vs sim time

`--hist` to display a histogram of RTF.
summary.html:
A runner for executing an SDF and recording simulation rates.

Can be used in conjunction with the plotting script to do

--summarize to get statistics about RTF

--plot to display a plot of RTF vs sim time

--hist to display a histogram of RTF.

values.description:
First step towards integrating a second physics engine.

Physics engine can be specified in sdf file in the same way as in Gazebo.

Default to `dart`.
values.title: Allow specifying physics engine in sdf file

First step towards integrating a second physics engine.

Physics engine can be specified in sdf file in the same way as in Gazebo.

Default to `dart`.

First step towards integrating a second physics engine.

Physics engine can be specified in sdf file in the same way as in Gazebo.

Default to dart.

values.description: This improves the performance of the pose publisher by caching entities and their scoped names. With 4 vehicles in the practice circuit 01, RTF went from ~15% to 24%. To get a better sense of the performance improvement, I commented out the Sensor system and with that, RTF went from 17% to 30%.
values.title: Improve performance of Pose Publisher

summary.raw: This improves the performance of the pose publisher by caching entities and their scoped names. With 4 vehicles in the practice circuit 01, RTF went from ~15% to 24%. To get a better sense of the performance improvement, I commented out the Sensor system and with that, RTF went from 17% to 30%.
summary.html: This improves the performance of the pose publisher by caching entities and their scoped names. With 4 vehicles in the practice circuit 01, RTF went from ~15% to 24%. To get a better sense of the performance improvement, I commented out the Sensor system and with that, RTF went from 17% to 30%.

values.description:
Two potential optimizations to consider that @{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} and I found this afternoon.

For SceneBroadcaster, defer updating poses until a publish is required in this update \(60Hz\).

For Sensors system, defer updating poses until a render operation is required in this update.
values.title: Performance: Throttle the SceneBroadcaster and render systems

summary.raw:
Two potential optimizations to consider that @{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} and I found this afternoon.

For SceneBroadcaster, defer updating poses until a publish is required in this update \(60Hz\).

For Sensors system, defer updating poses until a render operation is required in this update.
summary.html:
Two potential optimizations to consider that @Addisu Z. Taddese and I found this afternoon.

For SceneBroadcaster, defer updating poses until a publish is required in this update (60Hz).

For Sensors system, defer updating poses until a render operation is required in this update.

values.description:
Depends on [ign-common PR 200](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/200/log-resources/diff).

Ports [this Gazebo PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2811/save-models-material-and-meshes-when/diff) to Ignition.

Implements `--record-resources`, and `--log-compress` and `--log-overwrite` to support it.

Records resources \(`--record-resources`\), i.e. meshes and materials, to a directory under the specified log record directory. Optionally compresses \(`--log-compress`\) the whole directory, which contains the existing `.tlog` sqlite3 file and any resources, to a zip file. If directory or compressed file already exist, optionally overwrites \(`--log-overwrite`\).

Corresponding SDF plugin parameters: `<record_resources>1</record_resources>`, `<compress>1</compress>.`If both command line and SDF parameters are specified, command line option overwrites SDF parameter. `--log-overwrite` is handled on command line only, outside of the plugin. If recording is only enabled from SDF and not from command line, then behavior is to always overwrite.

## Usage:

```
ign gazebo [...] --record-resources --log-overwrite --log-compress
```

## Test --record-resources:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path /tmp/log
# (Re)move local downloaded Fuel copy of resources
$ mv ~/.ignition/fuel ~/.ignition/fuel_bak
# Play back from recorded resources
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r --playback /tmp/log
```

Tested with `<include><uri>https://fuel...</uri></include>` and `<mesh><uri>file://...</uri></mesh>`. Paths specified by `model://` are not supported in Ignition yet, so this case in the code is not tested.

## Test --log-overwrite and --log-compress:

When recording to `path`, the compression file is implied to be `path.zip`. Both are checked for existence.

No `--log-overwrite` \(default\):

```
# This SDF specifies the equivalent of --record-path '/tmp/log'
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf

# Run it again. By default it will always overwrite, because overwrite is now taken care of in ign.cc
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf
[Msg] Overwriting existing file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
```

`--log-overwrite`, `/tmp/log` already exists:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing path [/tmp/log]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

`--log-overwrite --log-compress`, `/tmp/log` exists, `/tmp/log.zip` does not exist:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing path [/tmp/log]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log].
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

`--log-overwrite --log-compress`, `/tmp/log` does not exist, `/tmp/log.zip` exists:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Wrn] [ign.cc:121] Compressed log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing compressed file [/tmp/log.zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log].
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

`--log-overwrite` only, `/tmp/log.zip` exists, `/tmp/log` does not exist:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Removing existing compressed file [/tmp/log.zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

`--log-compress` only, both `/tmp/log` and `/tmp/log.zip` already exist:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Wrn] [ign.cc:152] Log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(1)]
[Wrn] [ign.cc:154] Compressed log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(1).zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log(1)/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log(1).zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log(1)].
[Msg] Stopping recording
$ ls /tmp
log
'log(1).zip'
log.zip
```

`--log-compress` only, `/tmp/log` does not exist, `/tmp/log.zip` exists, `/tmp/log(1).zip` exists:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Wrn] [ign.cc:152] Log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(2)]
[Wrn] [ign.cc:154] Compressed log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(2).zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log(2)/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log(2).zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log(2)].
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

## Record Path vs. Console Log Path

In Blueprint and Citadel, if `--record` is specified without `--record-path`, and `<path>` exists in SDF, a warning is printed, and recording will go to `<path>`, while console log will go to the default timestamp path.

As in this example:

```
# SDF specifies <path>/tmp/log</path>
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --record --log-compress -log-overwrite
[Wrn] [ServerPrivate.cc:229] --record-path is not specified on command line. <path> is specified in SDF. Will record to <path>. Console will be logged to [/home/master/.ignition/gazebo/log/2019-09-20T19:51:33.996055619]. Note: In Ignition-D, <path> will be ignored, and all recordings will be written to default console log path if no path is specified on command line.
[Msg] Overwriting existing file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Removing existing file [/tmp/log.zip].
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log].
```

In Ignition-D, `<path>` will be permanently ignored. Recordings and console log will go to same default path.

If `--record-path` is specified, then recording and console log will go to this path in Blueprint, Citadel, and Ignition-D.

## Future Work

Files are outputted in `/tmp/log` and `/tmp/log.zip` in this example. During record, the original path in `file://` is prepended with the specified path, e.g. `/tmp/log`. During playback, the specified path is prepended to the URIs in the SDF.
values.title: [Blueprint] Logging meshes and materials

summary.raw:
Depends on [ign-common PR 200](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/200/log-resources/diff).

Ports [this Gazebo PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2811/save-models-material-and-meshes-when/diff) to Ignition.

Implements `--record-resources`, and `--log-compress` and `--log-overwrite` to support it.

Records resources \(`--record-resources`\), i.e. meshes and materials, to a directory under the specified log record directory. Optionally compresses \(`--log-compress`\) the whole directory, which contains the existing `.tlog` sqlite3 file and any resources, to a zip file. If directory or compressed file already exist, optionally overwrites \(`--log-overwrite`\).

Corresponding SDF plugin parameters: `<record_resources>1</record_resources>`, `<compress>1</compress>.`If both command line and SDF parameters are specified, command line option overwrites SDF parameter. `--log-overwrite` is handled on command line only, outside of the plugin. If recording is only enabled from SDF and not from command line, then behavior is to always overwrite.

## Usage:

```
ign gazebo [...] --record-resources --log-overwrite --log-compress
```

## Test --record-resources:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path /tmp/log
# (Re)move local downloaded Fuel copy of resources
$ mv ~/.ignition/fuel ~/.ignition/fuel_bak
# Play back from recorded resources
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r --playback /tmp/log
```

Tested with `<include><uri>https://fuel...</uri></include>` and `<mesh><uri>file://...</uri></mesh>`. Paths specified by `model://` are not supported in Ignition yet, so this case in the code is not tested.

## Test --log-overwrite and --log-compress:

When recording to `path`, the compression file is implied to be `path.zip`. Both are checked for existence.

No `--log-overwrite` \(default\):

```
# This SDF specifies the equivalent of --record-path '/tmp/log'
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf

# Run it again. By default it will always overwrite, because overwrite is now taken care of in ign.cc
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf
[Msg] Overwriting existing file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
```

`--log-overwrite`, `/tmp/log` already exists:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing path [/tmp/log]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

`--log-overwrite --log-compress`, `/tmp/log` exists, `/tmp/log.zip` does not exist:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing path [/tmp/log]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log].
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

`--log-overwrite --log-compress`, `/tmp/log` does not exist, `/tmp/log.zip` exists:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Wrn] [ign.cc:121] Compressed log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing compressed file [/tmp/log.zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log].
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

`--log-overwrite` only, `/tmp/log.zip` exists, `/tmp/log` does not exist:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Removing existing compressed file [/tmp/log.zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

`--log-compress` only, both `/tmp/log` and `/tmp/log.zip` already exist:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Wrn] [ign.cc:152] Log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(1)]
[Wrn] [ign.cc:154] Compressed log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(1).zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log(1)/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log(1).zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log(1)].
[Msg] Stopping recording
$ ls /tmp
log
'log(1).zip'
log.zip
```

`--log-compress` only, `/tmp/log` does not exist, `/tmp/log.zip` exists, `/tmp/log(1).zip` exists:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Wrn] [ign.cc:152] Log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(2)]
[Wrn] [ign.cc:154] Compressed log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(2).zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log(2)/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log(2).zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log(2)].
[Msg] Stopping recording
```

## Record Path vs. Console Log Path

In Blueprint and Citadel, if `--record` is specified without `--record-path`, and `<path>` exists in SDF, a warning is printed, and recording will go to `<path>`, while console log will go to the default timestamp path.

As in this example:

```
# SDF specifies <path>/tmp/log</path>
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --record --log-compress -log-overwrite
[Wrn] [ServerPrivate.cc:229] --record-path is not specified on command line. <path> is specified in SDF. Will record to <path>. Console will be logged to [/home/master/.ignition/gazebo/log/2019-09-20T19:51:33.996055619]. Note: In Ignition-D, <path> will be ignored, and all recordings will be written to default console log path if no path is specified on command line.
[Msg] Overwriting existing file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Removing existing file [/tmp/log.zip].
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log].
```

In Ignition-D, `<path>` will be permanently ignored. Recordings and console log will go to same default path.

If `--record-path` is specified, then recording and console log will go to this path in Blueprint, Citadel, and Ignition-D.

## Future Work

Files are outputted in `/tmp/log` and `/tmp/log.zip` in this example. During record, the original path in `file://` is prepended with the specified path, e.g. `/tmp/log`. During playback, the specified path is prepended to the URIs in the SDF.
summary.html:
Depends on ign-common PR 200.

Ports this Gazebo PR to Ignition.

Implements --record-resources, and --log-compress and --log-overwrite to support it.

Records resources (--record-resources), i.e. meshes and materials, to a directory under the specified log record directory. Optionally compresses (--log-compress) the whole directory, which contains the existing .tlog sqlite3 file and any resources, to a zip file. If directory or compressed file already exist, optionally overwrites (--log-overwrite).

Corresponding SDF plugin parameters: <record_resources>1</record_resources>, <compress>1</compress>.If both command line and SDF parameters are specified, command line option overwrites SDF parameter. --log-overwrite is handled on command line only, outside of the plugin. If recording is only enabled from SDF and not from command line, then behavior is to always overwrite.

Usage:

ign gazebo [...] --record-resources --log-overwrite --log-compress

Test --record-resources:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path /tmp/log
# (Re)move local downloaded Fuel copy of resources
$ mv ~/.ignition/fuel ~/.ignition/fuel_bak
# Play back from recorded resources
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r --playback /tmp/log

Tested with <include><uri>https://fuel...</uri></include> and <mesh><uri>file://...</uri></mesh>. Paths specified by model:// are not supported in Ignition yet, so this case in the code is not tested.

Test --log-overwrite and --log-compress:

When recording to path, the compression file is implied to be path.zip. Both are checked for existence.

No --log-overwrite (default):

# This SDF specifies the equivalent of --record-path '/tmp/log'
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf

# Run it again. By default it will always overwrite, because overwrite is now taken care of in ign.cc
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf
[Msg] Overwriting existing file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]

--log-overwrite, /tmp/log already exists:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing path [/tmp/log]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Stopping recording

--log-overwrite --log-compress, /tmp/log exists, /tmp/log.zip does not exist:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing path [/tmp/log]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log].
[Msg] Stopping recording

--log-overwrite --log-compress, /tmp/log does not exist, /tmp/log.zip exists:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Wrn] [ign.cc:121] Compressed log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten.
[Msg] Removing existing compressed file [/tmp/log.zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log].
[Msg] Stopping recording

--log-overwrite only, /tmp/log.zip exists, /tmp/log does not exist:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Msg] Removing existing compressed file [/tmp/log.zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Stopping recording

--log-compress only, both /tmp/log and /tmp/log.zip already exist:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Wrn] [ign.cc:152] Log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(1)]
[Wrn] [ign.cc:154] Compressed log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(1).zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log(1)/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log(1).zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log(1)].
[Msg] Stopping recording
$ ls /tmp
log
'log(1).zip'
log.zip

--log-compress only, /tmp/log does not exist, /tmp/log.zip exists, /tmp/log(1).zip exists:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'
[Wrn] [ign.cc:152] Log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(2)]
[Wrn] [ign.cc:154] Compressed log path already exists on disk! Recording instead to [/tmp/log(2).zip]
...
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log(2)/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log(2).zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log(2)].
[Msg] Stopping recording

Record Path vs. Console Log Path

In Blueprint and Citadel, if --record is specified without --record-path, and <path> exists in SDF, a warning is printed, and recording will go to <path>, while console log will go to the default timestamp path.

As in this example:

# SDF specifies <path>/tmp/log</path>
$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --record --log-compress -log-overwrite
[Wrn] [ServerPrivate.cc:229] --record-path is not specified on command line. <path> is specified in SDF. Will record to <path>. Console will be logged to [/home/master/.ignition/gazebo/log/2019-09-20T19:51:33.996055619]. Note: In Ignition-D, <path> will be ignored, and all recordings will be written to default console log path if no path is specified on command line.
[Msg] Overwriting existing file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]
...
[Msg] Removing existing file [/tmp/log.zip].
[Msg] Compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip].
Removing recorded directory [/tmp/log].

In Ignition-D, <path> will be permanently ignored. Recordings and console log will go to same default path.

If --record-path is specified, then recording and console log will go to this path in Blueprint, Citadel, and Ignition-D.

Future Work

Files are outputted in /tmp/log and /tmp/log.zip in this example. During record, the original path in file:// is prepended with the specified path, e.g. /tmp/log. During playback, the specified path is prepended to the URIs in the SDF.

values.description: This improves performance once levels get loaded and unloaded.
values.title: Clear stepMsg before populating it

summary.raw: This improves performance once levels get loaded and unloaded.
summary.html: This improves performance once levels get loaded and unloaded.

values.description:
There are 2 threads that are interesting for us in the GUI:

* `Scene3D`'s render thread: `RenderThread`
* The threads spun up on demand as the GUI runner receives a new state message: `GuiRunner::OnState`

Results running a SubT world:

## RenderThread

![render_thread.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/770033905-render_thread.png)
![render_thread_2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1429930800-render_thread_2.png)

Almost all the time is spend on `camera->Update()`


## GuiRunner::OnState

![onstate_thread.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2215345235-onstate_thread.png)
![onstate_thread_2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1157025931-onstate_thread_2.png)

The majority of time is spend on `RenderUtilPrivate::UpdateRenderingEntities`, which consists of several simple `Each` calls.

I tried consolidating all `Each` calls into a single one that gets all entities with a pose, even if rendering doesn't care about them, and that made the performance slightly worse.

~~~
   _ecm.Each<components::Pose>(
       [&](const Entity &_entity,
         const components::Pose *_pose)->bool
       {
         this->entityPoses[_entity] = _pose->Data();
         return true;
       });
~~~

---

With these preliminary results, I'm inclined to say that the client is processing well the incoming data. Therefore, delays on display are a result from the server being slow in publishing messages. I wouldn't say this is conclusive though.
values.title: Add profiling points to GUI

summary.raw:
There are 2 threads that are interesting for us in the GUI:

* `Scene3D`'s render thread: `RenderThread`
* The threads spun up on demand as the GUI runner receives a new state message: `GuiRunner::OnState`

Results running a SubT world:

## RenderThread

![render_thread.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/770033905-render_thread.png)
![render_thread_2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1429930800-render_thread_2.png)

Almost all the time is spend on `camera->Update()`


## GuiRunner::OnState

![onstate_thread.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2215345235-onstate_thread.png)
![onstate_thread_2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1157025931-onstate_thread_2.png)

The majority of time is spend on `RenderUtilPrivate::UpdateRenderingEntities`, which consists of several simple `Each` calls.

I tried consolidating all `Each` calls into a single one that gets all entities with a pose, even if rendering doesn't care about them, and that made the performance slightly worse.

~~~
   _ecm.Each<components::Pose>(
       [&](const Entity &_entity,
         const components::Pose *_pose)->bool
       {
         this->entityPoses[_entity] = _pose->Data();
         return true;
       });
~~~

---

With these preliminary results, I'm inclined to say that the client is processing well the incoming data. Therefore, delays on display are a result from the server being slow in publishing messages. I wouldn't say this is conclusive though.
summary.html:
There are 2 threads that are interesting for us in the GUI:

  • Scene3D's render thread: RenderThread
  • The threads spun up on demand as the GUI runner receives a new state message: GuiRunner::OnState

Results running a SubT world:

RenderThread

Almost all the time is spend on camera->Update()

GuiRunner::OnState

The majority of time is spend on RenderUtilPrivate::UpdateRenderingEntities, which consists of several simple Each calls.

I tried consolidating all Each calls into a single one that gets all entities with a pose, even if rendering doesn't care about them, and that made the performance slightly worse.

   _ecm.Each<components::Pose>(
       [&](const Entity &_entity,
         const components::Pose *_pose)->bool
       {
         this->entityPoses[_entity] = _pose->Data();
         return true;
       });

With these preliminary results, I'm inclined to say that the client is processing well the incoming data. Therefore, delays on display are a result from the server being slow in publishing messages. I wouldn't say this is conclusive though.
